Not medically necessary.what_it_means: The insurer claims your doctor's treatment recommendation doesn't meet their criteria for coverage, even though your doctor believes it's necessary for your health.
Not medically necessary.why_insurers_use_it: This is one of the most common denial reasons because it's vague and shifts the burden of proof to you. Insurers use it to avoid paying for expensive treatments.
how_to_counter: Get a detailed letter from your doctor explaining exactly why this treatment is necessary for your specific condition
Request the insurer's specific medical policy or criteria they used to make the denial
Cite medical guidelines and research supporting the treatment
Document how other treatments have failed or are inappropriate
Explain how delaying treatment could worsen your condition
Not medically necessary.success_rate: High - many denials are overturned with proper documentation

Non-formulary exception denied.what_it_means: Your medication isn't on the insurer's approved drug list (formulary), and they rejected your request to cover it anyway.
Non-formulary exception denied.why_insurers_use_it: Insurers negotiate lower prices for drugs on their formulary. They deny exceptions to push you toward cheaper alternatives.
how_to_counter: Document why formulary alternatives don't work for you (tried and failed, allergies, side effects)
Get your doctor to explain why this specific medication is medically necessary
Cite continuity of care protections if you were already taking this medication
Appeal using medical necessity and patient safety arguments
Consider filing a complaint with your state insurance department
Non-formulary exception denied.success_rate: Moderate - depends on documentation of failed alternatives

Provider out-of-network.what_it_means: Your doctor or facility isn't in the insurer's network, so they won't pay (or will pay less) for services.
Provider out-of-network.why_insurers_use_it: Networks are how insurers control costs. They want you to use providers they've negotiated lower rates with.
how_to_counter: Check if the service qualifies as emergency care (No Surprises Act protections apply)
Request a single-case agreement for in-network rates if no in-network specialist is available
Document lack of in-network providers in your area with your condition expertise
Appeal based on continuity of care if you're mid-treatment
File a network adequacy complaint with your state if appropriate specialists aren't available
Provider out-of-network.success_rate: Moderate - stronger for emergencies and specialist care

Prior authorization now required.what_it_means: The insurer changed their rules and now requires approval before providing a service or medication you were already receiving.
Prior authorization now required.why_insurers_use_it: Insurers add prior authorization requirements to create administrative hurdles that reduce utilization and costs.
how_to_counter: Request an expedited prior authorization if treatment is urgent
Cite continuity of care protections, especially if you're mid-treatment
Document how delays could harm your health
Check if your state has non-medical switching protections
Appeal the denial of the prior authorization with medical necessity documentation
Prior authorization now required.success_rate: High - especially with continuity of care arguments

Experimental or investigational.what_it_means: The insurer claims the treatment isn't proven effective or is still being researched, even if it's FDA-approved or guideline-recommended.
Experimental or investigational.why_insurers_use_it: It sounds scientific but is often outdated. Insurers may not update their policies when new evidence emerges.
how_to_counter: Show the treatment is FDA-approved for your condition
Cite medical society guidelines that recommend the treatment
Provide recent peer-reviewed studies demonstrating effectiveness
Get your doctor to explain why this is standard of care, not experimental
Request the insurer's specific policy and show it's outdated
Experimental or investigational.success_rate: High - often based on outdated policies

Step therapy required.what_it_means: You must try (and fail) cheaper treatments before the insurer will cover what your doctor prescribed.
Step therapy required.why_insurers_use_it: Cost control - they want you to exhaust cheaper options first, even if your doctor thinks they won't work.
how_to_counter: Document all previous treatments you've already tried and how they failed
Get your doctor to explain why those alternatives are medically inappropriate
Show that step therapy would cause harmful delays
Cite contraindications or drug interactions with required step therapies
Check if your state has step therapy exception laws
Step therapy required.success_rate: High - if you've already tried alternatives or they're contraindicated

Insufficient documentation.what_it_means: The insurer claims they don't have enough medical records or information to approve the treatment.
Insufficient documentation.why_insurers_use_it: It's a way to delay or deny without saying 'no' outright. Sometimes documentation was submitted but 'lost.'
how_to_counter: Request exactly what documentation they need in writing
Work with your doctor's office to submit comprehensive medical records
Send documentation via certified mail or with delivery confirmation
Include: diagnosis codes, treatment history, test results, doctor's notes, letter of medical necessity
Keep copies of everything you submit with dates and confirmation numbers
Insufficient documentation.success_rate: Very High - most succeed once proper documentation is submitted

Off-label use not covered.what_it_means: Your doctor prescribed a medication for a condition it's not FDA-approved to treat (though this is common and legal in medicine).
Off-label use not covered.why_insurers_use_it: Many effective treatments are used off-label. Insurers use this to avoid paying for expensive medications.
how_to_counter: Cite medical literature showing the off-label use is effective
Get your doctor to explain why on-label alternatives aren't appropriate
Reference major medical compendia (AHFS, DRUGDEX, NCCN) that support the use
Show this is standard of care in your medical community
Document that FDA-approved treatments for your condition have failed
Off-label use not covered.success_rate: Moderate - depends on strength of medical evidence

Cosmetic exclusion.what_it_means: The insurer claims the procedure is for appearance only, not medical necessity.
Cosmetic exclusion.why_insurers_use_it: To deny expensive procedures like reconstructive surgery, gender-affirming care, or dermatology treatments.
how_to_counter: Document functional impairments, not just appearance concerns
Show how the condition affects your daily life, work, or safety
Get mental health documentation if applicable (dysphoria, depression)
Cite medical guidelines showing the treatment is medically necessary
Distinguish between cosmetic and reconstructive/functional procedures
Cosmetic exclusion.success_rate: Moderate - stronger with functional impairment documentation

Maintenance care only.what_it_means: The insurer claims you're just maintaining your current condition, not improving, so they won't cover ongoing therapy.
Maintenance care only.why_insurers_use_it: To cut off physical therapy, occupational therapy, or chronic condition management.
how_to_counter: Show objective measures of ongoing improvement (strength, range of motion, function)
Document that stopping therapy would lead to decline
Distinguish between maintenance and preventing deterioration
Get your therapist to explain why continued treatment is restorative
Cite Medicare and medical guidelines that support coverage
Maintenance care only.success_rate: Moderate - requires documenting functional goals and progress

Exceeds benefit limits.what_it_means: You've hit a cap on visits, days, or dollar amount for a service this year.
Exceeds benefit limits.why_insurers_use_it: Arbitrary limits that may not reflect medical necessity or state/federal requirements.
how_to_counter: Check if the limit violates state or federal parity laws (especially mental health)
Request an exception based on medical necessity
Document why additional services are critical for your recovery
Compare to coverage of similar medical conditions
File a parity complaint if mental health/substance use limits are stricter than medical

Not an emergency.what_it_means: The insurer claims your ER visit or urgent treatment wasn't truly an emergency, so they won't pay.
Not an emergency.why_insurers_use_it: To avoid paying high ER costs based on hindsight, not what you reasonably believed at the time.
how_to_counter: Cite the 'prudent layperson' standard - would a reasonable person think this was an emergency?
Document your symptoms at the time (chest pain, severe bleeding, difficulty breathing, etc.)
Show you couldn't have known the final diagnosis without emergency evaluation
Reference emergency medicine guidelines supporting evaluation of your symptoms
Some states prohibit retrospective ER denials
Not an emergency.success_rate: High - prudent layperson standard protects patients

Pre-existing condition exclusion.what_it_means: The insurer claims your condition existed before your coverage started, so they won't pay.
Pre-existing condition exclusion.why_insurers_use_it: Mostly illegal now under the ACA for major medical plans, but may appear in limited plans.
how_to_counter: Confirm this is illegal for ACA-compliant plans and most employer plans
If a short-term or excepted benefit plan, review the specific exclusion language
Document that the condition was not diagnosed or treated before coverage
Show this is a new manifestation or complication, not the original condition
File a complaint with your state insurance department if ACA applies
Pre-existing condition exclusion.success_rate: Depends on insurance type, 2026 may be complicated by people switching to non-ACA plans.

Timely filing limit exceeded.what_it_means: The claim was submitted too late according to the insurer's deadline.
Timely filing limit exceeded.why_insurers_use_it: A technicality to avoid paying claims, even if the delay wasn't your fault.
how_to_counter: Check if your state has laws limiting how short timely filing periods can be
Document if the delay was due to the provider, insurer error, or coordination of benefits issues
Request an exception if you had good cause for the delay
Show you submitted claims as soon as you knew coverage was denied
File a complaint with your state if the insurer didn't provide adequate notice of the requirement

If an in-network provider failed to submit on time, it may be the providers responsibility instead of the patient; this can be complicated but may be a case where your insurance company can actually help.
Timely filing limit exceeded.success_rate: Lower - depends on reason for delay

Gender dysphoria not documented.what_it_means: The insurer claims there's insufficient evidence you have a gender dysphoria diagnosis requiring treatment.
Gender dysphoria not documented.why_insurers_use_it: To deny gender-affirming care by imposing arbitrary documentation requirements.
how_to_counter: Provide letters from mental health providers confirming gender dysphoria diagnosis
Reference WPATH Standards of Care that support the treatment
Document persistent gender dysphoria and impact on functioning
Show treatment plan is consistent with medical guidelines
Challenge any requirements that exceed WPATH/medical standards
Gender dysphoria not documented.success_rate: High - with proper clinical documentation. May change as laws evolve.
